title: Using Contrasts
code: data(lui_sim)

title: Using Contrasts
text: Forward search
code: config_mod <- " f1 =~ class1 + class2 + class3 + class4 + class5 + class6 +        class7 + class8 + class9 + class10 + class11 + class12 +        class13 + class14 + class15 " config_fit <- cfa(config_mod, data = lui_sim, group = "group", ordered = TRUE) # Release covariance between class1 and class2 config_fit2 <- update(config_fit, c(config_mod, "class1 ~~ class2")) anova(config_fit, config_fit2) #>  #> Scaled Chi-Squared Difference Test (method = "satorra.2000") #>  #> lavaan NOTE: #>     The "Chisq" column contains standard test statistics, not the #>     robust test that should be reported per model. A robust difference #>     test is a function of two standard (not robust) statistics. #>   #>              Df AIC BIC  Chisq Chisq diff Df diff Pr(>Chisq)     #> config_fit2 534         354.80                                   #> config_fit  540         411.35     36.784       6   1.94e-06 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 knitr::kable(ps[[2]])

title: Using Contrasts
text: \(f_\text{MACS}\) effect sizes
code: # Obtain fmacs effect size (f_omni <- pin_effsize(ps[[1]])) #>       class1-f1 class2-f1 class3-f1  class4-f1 class5-f1 class6-f1  class7-f1 #> fmacs 0.1199449 0.1105255  0.238074 0.09092291 0.0495783 0.1858896 0.09463213 #>       class8-f1 class9-f1 class10-f1 class11-f1 class12-f1 class13-f1 #> fmacs 0.1744843 0.1149672  0.1268064 0.03537658   0.108777 0.07085813 #>       class14-f1 class15-f1 #> fmacs   0.186054   0.142585 # fmacs by gender (f_gender <- pin_effsize(ps[[1]], group_factor = c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2))) #>        class1-f1  class2-f1 class3-f1 class4-f1  class5-f1  class6-f1 #> fmacs 0.03579684 0.03298566 0.1443419 0.0271354 0.03031563 0.04858562 #>        class7-f1  class8-f1  class9-f1 class10-f1 class11-f1 class12-f1 #> fmacs 0.02824239 0.03521752 0.08328992 0.04836614 0.01813995 0.01888032 #>       class13-f1 class14-f1 class15-f1 #> fmacs 0.02702651   0.031373 0.04375972 # fmacs by ethnicity (f_eth <- pin_effsize(ps[[1]], group_factor = c(1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3))) #>        class1-f1  class2-f1 class3-f1  class4-f1  class5-f1 class6-f1 #> fmacs 0.05810994 0.05354648 0.1249765 0.04404959 0.01246573 0.1131984 #>        class7-f1  class8-f1  class9-f1 class10-f1 class11-f1 class12-f1 #> fmacs 0.04584661 0.08974653 0.07569014 0.07851401 0.02558757 0.08674763 #>       class13-f1 class14-f1 class15-f1 #> fmacs 0.04387283 0.07597534  0.1148142 # interaction (using contrast matrix) contr <- local({     gen <- factor(c("F", "M"))     contrasts(gen) <- contr.sum(length(gen))     eth <- factor(1:3)     contrasts(eth) <- contr.sum(length(eth))     model.matrix(~ gen * eth, data = expand.grid(eth = eth, gen = gen)) }) (f_int <- pin_effsize(ps[[1]], contrast = contr[, 5:6, drop = FALSE])) #>        class1-f1  class2-f1 class3-f1  class4-f1  class5-f1 class6-f1 #> fmacs 0.05810994 0.05354648 0.1641631 0.04404959 0.04276347 0.1131984 #>        class7-f1 class8-f1  class9-f1 class10-f1 class11-f1 class12-f1 #> fmacs 0.04584661 0.1309964 0.07569014 0.07851401 0.02558757 0.08674763 #>       class13-f1 class14-f1 class15-f1 #> fmacs 0.04387283  0.1208214 0.07983449 # Render as table item_names <- gsub("class", replacement = "Item ", colnames(f_omni)) |>     gsub(pattern = "-f1", replacement = "") t(rbind(f_omni, f_gender, f_eth, f_int)) |>     as.data.frame() |>     `dimnames<-`(list(         item_names,         c("Overall", "Gender", "Ethnicity", "Gender x Ethnicity")     )) |>     knitr::kable(digits = 2, caption = "$f_\\text{MACS}$ effect sizes")

title: (P)artial (in)variance specification search
text: suggested workflow using main function pinSearch() Define lavaan syntax configural invariance model. Conduct pinSearch() specific test statistic stopping criteria. default use modification indices Yoon Millsap (2007), score test also supported. function returns final partial invariance model list noninvariant parameters search order. Obtain effect size statistics noninvariant items.

title: (P)artial (in)variance specification search
text: use classic data set Holzinger & Swineford, goal searching partial strict invariance model. noninvariant parameters: final partial invariance model

title: (P)artial (in)variance specification search
text: package supports \(d_\text{MACS}\) effect size statistics Nye Drasgow (2011) noninvariant items, generalization \(f_\text{bias}\) statistic two groups. can obtained setting effect_size = TRUE argument: Note output, effect sizes printed three times x3 x7, non-invariant intercepts. three latent variables model, function allows possibility cross-loadings. item loaded one latent variable, user can ignore duplicated values (try fix future releases). Another possibility use pin_effsize() function, also works partial invariance model obtained pinSearch().
code: pinSearch(mod,     data = HolzingerSwineford1939,     group = "school", type = "residuals",     inv_test = "mod",     effect_size = TRUE ) #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 64 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        66 #>   Number of equality constraints                    25 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     Pasteur                                        156 #>     Grant-White                                    145 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                               147.260 #>   Degrees of freedom                                67 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     Pasteur                                     79.438 #>     Grant-White                                 67.823 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     1  x3     intercepts #> 2     1  x7     intercepts #>  #> $effect_size #>       x3-visual x7-visual x3-textual x7-textual  x3-speed  x7-speed #> dmacs 0.4865937 0.4161147  0.4865937  0.4161147 0.4865937 0.4161147 # Fit the partial strict model by hand pstrict_fit <- cfa(mod, data = HolzingerSwineford1939,                    group = "school",                    group.equal = c("loadings", "intercepts",                                    "residuals"),                    group.partial = c("x3~1", "x7~1")) # Effect sizes pin_effsize(pstrict_fit) #>       x3-visual x7-visual x3-textual x7-textual  x3-speed  x7-speed #> dmacs 0.4865945 0.4161159  0.4865945  0.4161159 0.4865945 0.4161159

title: (P)artial (in)variance specification search
text: function also supports models cross-loadings. example, just happened examplle final results affected.
code: mod2 <- "    visual  =~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x9   textual =~ x4 + x5 + x6   speed   =~ x7 + x8 + x9 " ps2 <-     pinSearch(mod2,         data = HolzingerSwineford1939,         group = "school", type = "residuals",         inv_test = "mod",         effect_size = TRUE     ) ps2 #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 55 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        68 #>   Number of equality constraints                    26 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     Pasteur                                        156 #>     Grant-White                                    145 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                               113.828 #>   Degrees of freedom                                66 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     Pasteur                                     67.913 #>     Grant-White                                 45.915 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     1  x3     intercepts #> 2     1  x7     intercepts #>  #> $effect_size #>       x3-visual x7-visual x3-textual x7-textual  x3-speed  x7-speed #> dmacs 0.4721376 0.4069837  0.4721376  0.4069837 0.4721376 0.4069837

title: (P)artial (in)variance specification search
text: One can also use score test instead modification indices, starting version 0.6-17, lavaan recommends using equality constraints. can achieved inv_test = "score". test slightly sensitive identifies additional non-invariant uniqueness item x7.
code: pinSearch(mod2,     data = HolzingerSwineford1939,     group = "school", type = "residuals",     inv_test = "score",     effect_size = TRUE ) #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 59 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        68 #>   Number of equality constraints                    25 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     Pasteur                                        156 #>     Grant-White                                    145 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                               109.770 #>   Degrees of freedom                                65 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     Pasteur                                     66.273 #>     Grant-White                                 43.497 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     2  x3     intercepts #> 2     2  x7     intercepts #> 3     2  x7  x7  residuals #>  #> $effect_size #>       x3-visual x7-visual x3-textual x7-textual  x3-speed  x7-speed #> dmacs 0.4717618 0.4071113  0.4717618  0.4071113 0.4717618 0.4071113

title: (P)artial (in)variance specification search
text: LRT generally accurate, computationally expensive. example, results using LRT score test.
code: pinSearch(mod2,     data = HolzingerSwineford1939,     group = "school", type = "residuals",     inv_test = "lrt",     effect_size = TRUE ) #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 59 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        68 #>   Number of equality constraints                    25 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     Pasteur                                        156 #>     Grant-White                                    145 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                               109.770 #>   Degrees of freedom                                65 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     Pasteur                                     66.273 #>     Grant-White                                 43.497 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     1  x3     intercepts #> 2     1  x7     intercepts #> 3     1  x7  x7  residuals #>  #> $effect_size #>       x3-visual x7-visual x3-textual x7-textual  x3-speed  x7-speed #> dmacs 0.4717618 0.4071113  0.4717618  0.4071113 0.4717618 0.4071113

title: (P)artial (in)variance specification search
text: function also supports adjusting multiplicity using stringent threshold flagging parameter noninvariant, using multistage false discovery rate procedure Benjamini & Gavrilov (2009) forward selection. debate whether controlling false discovery rate important measurement/factorial invariance analyses context, probably depends whether one interested identifying non-invariant items inferences latent parameters. interest, one can use control_fdr = TRUE option. uniqueness x7 longer flagged.
code: pinSearch(mod2,     data = HolzingerSwineford1939,     group = "school", type = "residuals",     inv_test = "score",     effect_size = TRUE,     control_fdr = TRUE ) #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 55 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        68 #>   Number of equality constraints                    26 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     Pasteur                                        156 #>     Grant-White                                    145 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                               113.828 #>   Degrees of freedom                                66 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     Pasteur                                     67.913 #>     Grant-White                                 45.915 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     2  x3     intercepts #> 2     2  x7     intercepts #>  #> $effect_size #>       x3-visual x7-visual x3-textual x7-textual  x3-speed  x7-speed #> dmacs 0.4721376 0.4069837  0.4721376  0.4069837 0.4721376 0.4069837

title: Authors and Citation
text: Mark Lai. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lai M (2024). pinsearch: Specification search partial factorial invariance. R package version 0.1.4.1,  https://marklhc.github.io/pinsearch/, https://github.com/marklhc/pinsearch.
code: @Manual{,   title = {pinsearch: Specification search for partial factorial invariance},   author = {Mark Lai},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.4.1,  https://marklhc.github.io/pinsearch/},   url = {https://github.com/marklhc/pinsearch}, }

what: Specification search for partial factorial invariance
title: Specification search for partial factorial invariance
text: goal pinsearch automate process performing specification search identifying noninvariant items arrive partial factorial invariance model.

title: Specification search for partial factorial invariance
text: can install development version pinsearch GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("marklhc/pinsearch")

title: Specification search for partial factorial invariance
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(pinsearch) library(lavaan) #> This is lavaan 0.6-17 #> lavaan is FREE software! Please report any bugs. HS.model <- '  visual =~ x1 + x2 + x3               textual =~ x4 + x5 + x6               speed   =~ x7 + x8 + x9 ' # Output the final partial invariance model, and the noninvariant items pinSearch(HS.model, data = HolzingerSwineford1939,            group = "school", type = "intercepts") #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 69 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        66 #>   Number of equality constraints                    16 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     Pasteur                                        156 #>     Grant-White                                    145 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                               129.422 #>   Degrees of freedom                                58 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     Pasteur                                     71.170 #>     Grant-White                                 58.253 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     1  x3     intercepts #> 2     1  x7     intercepts # Compute dmacs effect size (added in version 0.1.2) pinSearch(HS.model, data = HolzingerSwineford1939,            group = "school", type = "intercepts",           effect_size = TRUE,           progress = TRUE) #>  #> [1/2] Searching for loadings noninvariance #>  #> [2/2] Searching for intercepts noninvariance #>   |                                                                              |                                                                      |   0%  |                                                                              |==================                                                    |  25%  |                                                                              |====================================================                  |  75% #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 69 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        66 #>   Number of equality constraints                    16 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     Pasteur                                        156 #>     Grant-White                                    145 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                               129.422 #>   Degrees of freedom                                58 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     Pasteur                                     71.170 #>     Grant-White                                 58.253 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     1  x3     intercepts #> 2     1  x7     intercepts #>  #> $effect_size #>       x3-visual x7-visual x3-textual x7-textual  x3-speed  x7-speed #> dmacs 0.4824515 0.4161323  0.4824515  0.4161323 0.4824515 0.4161323

title: Specification search for partial factorial invariance
text: simulated example ordinal data
code: # Simulate data set.seed(2110) library(MASS) num_obs <- 500 lambda1 <- seq(.9, .6, length.out = 7) lambda2 <- c(lambda1[1], 1, lambda1[3:7]) cov1 <- tcrossprod(lambda1) + diag(.5, 7) dimnames(cov1) <- list(paste0("yy", 1:7), paste0("yy", 1:7)) thres1 <- rbind(seq(-1.5, 1.5, length.out = 7)) thres2 <- rbind(c(thres1[1], 0.25, thres1[3:6], 0.3)) mean1 <- rep(0, 7) ystar1 <- mvrnorm(num_obs, mu = mean1, Sigma = cov1) y1 <- ystar1 cov2 <- tcrossprod(lambda1) * 1.3 + diag(.5, 7) dimnames(cov2) <- dimnames(cov1) mean2 <- lambda1 * .4 ystar2 <- mvrnorm(num_obs, mu = mean2, Sigma = cov2) y2 <- ystar2 # Ordinal indicators thres1 <- rbind(seq(-1.5, 0, length.out = 7),                 seq(-0.5, 0.25, length.out = 7),                 rep(1, 7)) thres2 <- rbind(c(thres1[1, 1], -0.5, thres1[1, 3:6], -0.5),                 thres1[2,],                 c(rep(1, 3), rep(0.5, 2), rep(1, 2))) for (j in seq_len(ncol(ystar1))) {     y1[, j] <- findInterval(ystar1[, j], thres1[, j]) } for (j in seq_len(ncol(ystar2))) {     y2[, j] <- findInterval(ystar2[, j], thres2[, j]) } df <- rbind(cbind(y1, group = 1), cbind(y2, group = 2)) pinSearch(' f =~ yy1 + yy2 + yy3 + yy4 + yy5 + yy6 + yy7 ',           data = df, group = "group", type = "thresholds",           ordered = paste0("yy", 1:7),           effect_size = TRUE) #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 52 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                       DWLS #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        58 #>   Number of equality constraints                    24 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     1                                              500 #>     2                                              500 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                               Standard      Scaled #>   Test Statistic                                31.911      49.933 #>   Degrees of freedom                                50          50 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.978       0.476 #>   Scaling correction factor                                  0.745 #>   Shift parameter                                            7.073 #>     simple second-order correction                                 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     1                                           14.835      23.461 #>     2                                           17.077      26.472 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     1 yy2  t1 thresholds #> 2     2 yy7  t1 thresholds #> 3     1 yy5  t3 thresholds #> 4     1 yy4  t3 thresholds #>  #> $effect_size #>           yy2-f     yy4-f     yy5-f     yy7-f #> dmacs 0.2376422 0.1181811 0.1662268 0.2071426

what: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
title: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
text: dmacs returns dMACS effect size statistics given set loadings intercepts.

title: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
code: dmacs(   intercepts,   loadings = NULL,   pooled_item_sd,   latent_mean = 0,   latent_sd = 1 )  dmacs_ordered(   thresholds,   loadings,   thetas = 1,   link = c("probit", "logit"),   pooled_item_sd = NULL,   latent_mean = 0,   latent_sd = 1 )

title: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
text: intercepts \(2 \times p\) matrix measurement intercepts. loadings \(2 \times p\) matrix factor loadings, p number items. pooled_item_sd numeric vector length p pooled standard deviation (SD) items across groups. latent_mean latent factor mean reference group. Default 0. latent_sd latent factor SD reference group. Default 1. thresholds matrix two rows measurement thresholds. matrix must column names indicating item index column corresponds. thetas currently used. link Link function model (probit logit).

title: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
text: 1 x p matrix dMACS effect size.

title: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
text:
\(d_	ext{MACS}\) effect size defined (Nye & Drasgow, 2011, p. 968) $$d_{	ext{MACS}, } =  rac{1}{\mathit{SD}_{iP}}   \sqrt{\int [(
u_{iR} - 
u{}) +               (\lambda_{iR} - \lambda_{}) \eta]^2 f(\eta) d \eta}$$ \(\lambda\) loading \(
u\) intercept, F R denote focal reference group. effect size reflects standardized mean difference item due measurement noninvariance, analogous Cohen's d effect size.

title: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
text: Nye, C. & Drasgow, F. (2011). Effect size indices analyses measurement equivalence: Understanding practical importance differences groups. Journal Applied Psychology, 96(5), 966-980.

title: Compute dMACS effect size described in Nye & Drasgow (2011) for two groups. — dmacs
code: lambdaf <- c(.8, .5, .7, .5) lambdar <- c(.8, .5, .4, .6) nuf <- c(0.1, 0, 0.2, 0) nur <- c(0.2, 0, 0, 0) dmacs(rbind(nuf, nur),       loadings = rbind(lambdaf, lambdar),       pooled_item_sd = c(1, 1, 1, 1),       latent_mean = 0,       latent_sd = 1) #>       [,1] [,2]      [,3] [,4] #> dmacs  0.1    0 0.3605551  0.1 # Thresholds lambda <- rbind(c(.8, .5, .7, .5),                 c(.8, .5, .4, .6)) tau <- rbind(c(-0.5, 0, 1, -0.3, 0.1, 0.5, -0.5, 1.5),              c(-0.5, 0, 1, -0.5, 0.3, 0.5, -1, 1.5)) # three thresholds for items 1 and 2; one threshold for items 3 and 4 colnames(tau) <- c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4) dmacs_ordered(tau,               loadings = lambda,               pooled_item_sd = c(1, 1, 1, 1),               latent_mean = 0,               latent_sd = 1) #>       [,1]       [,2]      [,3]       [,4] #> dmacs    0 0.01711254 0.2019787 0.02276356

what: Item-level effect size for non-invariance — es_lavaan
title: Item-level effect size for non-invariance — es_lavaan
text: two groups, function uses dmacs() compute \(d_\text{MACS}\). two groups, function uses fmacs() compute \(f_\text{MACS}\), generalisation \(d_\text{MACS}\) similar Cohen's \(f\) effect size.

title: Item-level effect size for non-invariance — es_lavaan
code: es_lavaan(object, ...)  pin_effsize(object, ...)

title: Item-level effect size for non-invariance — es_lavaan
text: object CFA model class lavaan::lavaan fitted lavaan::cfa() ... Additional arguments passed dmacs() fmacs()

title: Item-level effect size for non-invariance — es_lavaan
text: matrix 1 row showing effect size values non-invariant item latent variable.

what: Compute fMACS effect size for two or more groups. — fmacs
title: Compute fMACS effect size for two or more groups. — fmacs
text: fmacs returns fMACS effect size statistics given set loadings intercepts.

title: Compute fMACS effect size for two or more groups. — fmacs
code: fmacs(   intercepts,   loadings = NULL,   pooled_item_sd,   num_obs = NULL,   weights = 0 * intercepts + 1,   group_factor = NULL,   contrast = contr.sum(nrow(intercepts)),   latent_mean = 0,   latent_sd = 1 )  fmacs_ordered(   thresholds,   loadings,   thetas = 1,   num_obs = NULL,   weights = 0 * loadings + 1,   group_factor = NULL,   contrast = contr.sum(nrow(thresholds)),   link = c("probit", "logit"),   pooled_item_sd = NULL,   latent_mean = 0,   latent_sd = 1 )

title: Compute fMACS effect size for two or more groups. — fmacs
text: intercepts \(G \times p\) matrix measurement intercepts. loadings \(G \times p\) matrix factor loadings, p number items G number groups. pooled_item_sd numeric vector length p pooled standard deviation (SD) items across groups. num_obs vector length \(G\) sample sizes. NULL, weights proportional sample sizes, assuming weights across items. weights \(G \times p\) matrix weights. Default assumes equal weights across groups. group_factor vector length \(G\) indicating grouping contrast. example, c(1, 1, 2) means contrasting Group 1 & 2 vs. Group 3. default combine groups, meaning omnibus effect computed. contrast \(p \times k\) contrast matrix colSums(contrast) = 0. Default contr.sum(p) group_factor specified. latent_mean latent factor mean reference group. Default 0. latent_sd latent factor SD reference group. Default 1. thresholds matrix G rows measurement thresholds. matrix must column names indicating item index column corresponds. thetas currently used. link Link function model (probit logit).

title: Compute fMACS effect size for two or more groups. — fmacs
text: 1 x p matrix fMACS effect size.

title: Compute fMACS effect size for two or more groups. — fmacs
text:
\(f_	ext{MACS}\) effect size defined $$f_{	ext{MACS}, } =  rac{1}{\mathit{SD}_{iP}}   \sqrt{\int [(
u_{ij} -  ar{
u}_j) +               (\lambda_{ij} -  ar{\lambda}_j) \eta]^2 f(\eta) d \eta}$$ \(\lambda\) loading \(
u\) intercept, j indexes group. effect size reflects square root ratio variance observed item score due measurement noninvariance variance observed item scores. \(f_	ext{MACS}\) analogous Cohen's f effect size. two groups equal sample sizes, \(f_	ext{MACS}\) = \(f_	ext{MACS}\) / 2

title: Compute fMACS effect size for two or more groups. — fmacs
code: lambda <- rbind(c(.7, .8, .7, .9),                 c(.7, .8, .7, .8),                 c(.8, .7, .7, .5)) nu <- rbind(c(0, .5, 0, 1),             c(0, .2, 0, 1.1),             c(0, .3, 0, 1.2)) fmacs(lambda,       loadings = nu,       pooled_item_sd = c(1, 1, 1, 1),       latent_mean = 0,       latent_sd = 1) #>             [,1]      [,2] [,3]      [,4] #> fmacs 0.04714045 0.1333333    0 0.1885618 # With contrast (Group 1 & 2 vs. Group 3) fmacs(lambda,       loadings = nu,       pooled_item_sd = c(1, 1, 1, 1),       group_factor = c(1, 1, 2),       latent_mean = 0,       latent_sd = 1) #>             [,1]       [,2] [,3]      [,4] #> fmacs 0.04714045 0.05270463    0 0.1795055 # Thresholds lambda <- rbind(c(.8, .5, .7, .5),                 c(.8, .5, .4, .6),                 c(.8, .7, .7, .5)) tau <- rbind(c(-0.5, 0, 1, -0.3, 0.1, 0.5, -0.5, 1.5),              c(-0.5, 0, 1, -0.5, 0.3, 0.5, -1, 1.5),              c(-0.5, 0, 1, -0.5, 0.3, 0.5, -1, 0.5)) # three thresholds for items 1 and 2; one threshold for items 3 and 4 colnames(tau) <- c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4) fmacs_ordered(tau,               loadings = lambda,               pooled_item_sd = c(1, 1, 1, 1),               latent_mean = 0,               latent_sd = 1) #>       [,1]       [,2]       [,3]      [,4] #> fmacs    0 0.06906871 0.08713051 0.1169068 # With contrast (Group 1 & 2 vs. Group 3) fmacs_ordered(tau,               loadings = lambda,               pooled_item_sd = c(1, 1, 1, 1),               group_factor = c(1, 2, 1),               latent_mean = 0,               latent_sd = 1) #>       [,1]       [,2]       [,3]       [,4] #> fmacs    0 0.04029493 0.06394493 0.05383212

what: Simulated data with 15 items of an Alcohol Belief Scale — lui_sim

title: Simulated data with 15 items of an Alcohol Belief Scale — lui_sim
code: lui_sim

text: data frame 910 rows 16 columns: class1 class15 Binary items group six groups: 1 = White Male, 2 = Asian Male, 3 = Hispanic Male, 4 = White Female, 5 = Asian Female, 6 = Hispanic Female

title: Simulated data with 15 items of an Alcohol Belief Scale — lui_sim
text: https://osf.io/wxjsg

what: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
title: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
text: function implements sequential selection method similar discussed Yoon Millsap (2007). function proceeds order metric, scalar (threshold), strict invariance. stage, invariance constraints items, constraint associated biggest test statistic predefined threshold freed, recomputing test statistic next constraint free.

title: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
code: pinSearch(   config_mod,   ...,   type = c("loadings", "intercepts", "thresholds", "residuals", "residual.covariances"),   inv_test = c("mod", "score", "lrt"),   sig_level = 0.05,   control_fdr = FALSE,   effect_size = FALSE,   progress = FALSE )

title: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
text: config_mod Syntax configural invariance model passed lavaan::cfa(). ... Additonal arguments passed lavaan::cfa(). type Character variable indicating stage invariance searched. Currently supported options () continuous indicators, "loadings", "intercepts", "residuals", "residual.covariances", (b) "loadings", "thresholds", "residual.covariances", increasingly strict order. stricter model (e.g., "residual.covariances") constraints previous stages. inv_test Character variable indicating statistical test used specification search. Currently supported options "mod" modification index using lavaan::modindices(), "score" score test statistic using lavaan::lavTestScore(), (experimental) "lrt" likelihood ratio test statistic using lavaan::lavTestLRT(). sig_level Significance level used determine whether parameter associated highest modification index removed. Default .05. control_fdr Logical; whether use adjust false discovery rate multiple testing. TRUE, method Benjamini & Gavrilov (2009) used. effect_size Logical; whether compute dmacs (two groups) fmacs (> two groups) effect size (default). experimental feature. progress Logical; experimental feature showing progress bar TRUE. number steps unknown stopping criteria reached, progress bar may inaccurate.

title: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
text: list three elements: Partial Invariance Fit: lavaan::lavaan object containing final partial invariance model. Non-Invariant Items: data frame non-invariant parameters. effect_size: Effect size statistics obtained pin_effsize().

title: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
text: Note item non-invariant loading, corresponding intercept constraint automatically freed, intercept difference across groups sensitive location zero point latent variable item. particular stage invariance constraints, Benjamini & Gavrilov method uses adjusted \(alpha\) level $$iq / [m + 1 - (1 - q)]$$ \(\) step index search, \(m\) maximum number constraints can freed, \(q\) desirable significance level.

title: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
text: Yoon, M., & Millsap, R. E. (2007). Detecting violations factorial invariance using data-based specification searches: Monte Carlo study. Structural Equation Modeling: Multidisciplinary Journal, 14(3), 435-463.

title: Search for noninvariant parameters across groups. — pinSearch
code: library(lavaan) #> This is lavaan 0.6-17 #> lavaan is FREE software! Please report any bugs. library(MASS) # Simulate random data set.seed(14) # for reproducible results mod_ninv <- "f =~ c(1, 0.8, .6)*y1 + c(0.8, 1.2, 1.0)*y2" mod_inv <- paste0("1*y", 3:6, collapse = " + ") sim_mod <- paste(     paste(mod_ninv, "+", mod_inv),     "f ~~ c(1, 1.3, 1.5)*f      f ~ c(0, 0.5, 1.0)*1      y1 ~ c(0, 0.3, 0)*1      y3 ~ c(0.3, 0, -0.3)*1      y1 ~~ c(1, .5, 1)*y1",     sep = "\n" ) # The uniqueness of each item is assumed to be 1.0 dat_sim <- simulateData(sim_mod, sample.nobs = c(100, 100, 100)) # Fit configural model: sam_config <- paste(     paste0("f =~ ", paste0("y", 1:6, collapse = " + ")) ) pinSearch(sam_config,     data = dat_sim, group = "group",     type = "intercepts" ) #> $`Partial Invariance Fit` #> lavaan 0.6.17 ended normally after 55 iterations #>  #>   Estimator                                         ML #>   Optimization method                           NLMINB #>   Number of model parameters                        58 #>   Number of equality constraints                    23 #>  #>   Number of observations per group:                    #>     1                                              100 #>     2                                              100 #>     3                                              100 #>  #> Model Test User Model: #>                                                        #>   Test statistic                                55.735 #>   Degrees of freedom                                46 #>   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.154 #>   Test statistic for each group: #>     1                                           23.938 #>     2                                           15.880 #>     3                                           15.917 #>  #> $`Non-Invariant Items` #>   group lhs rhs       type #> 1     2  y1     intercepts #>
